content.raw:
From the perspective of ign-msgs, we should depend on anything that solves the problem correctly. So far I haven't seen a technical or practical reason not to depend on ign-common. Size of dependency does not strike me as a point of concern, and we never look at the size of an external dependency. 

Static casting to an `int` relies on both ign-common and ign-msgs staying in sync with each other. By doing this we would be enforcing an implicit dependency, without making it explicit. In my mind this is worse than depending on ign-common.
